comment.author: 8139976@N03
comment._content: This picture was most recently published in Max Arthur's "Faces of World War I". There you can also find the myth that Kaiser Wilhelm put Barney Hines on his personal Most Wanted list, whatever that means.

comment.author: 77832619@N06
comment._content:
Hello all, this particular WW1 photograph in sepia tones represents the common soldier in the field during a very conflicting war in Europe that basically ended monarchies and rewrote country boundary lines. 
There were about 16 official photographers in Britain at the beginning of the WW1 who were assigned to the front to take documentary photographs. Back in those days, the war at the front was very controlled and news and photographs were censored heavily by the government and were most often taken for propaganda purposes.
It is interesting that now in the digital age, there is a movement to documnet and preserve these images as best as possible.
Thanks for letting me share.

comment.author: 61109118@N02
comment._content: I love to explore the picture to see how many different souvenirs he has gathered. I wonder if all of them were taken from dead enemies.

comment.author: 48809099@N02
comment._content: I thought the sappers had enough junk to lug around without this amount of booty as well? Fantastic image, he looks slightly mad.

comment.author: 78598560@N00
comment._content: Post Traumatic Stress Disorder is the heaviest weight he has to carry.  It writes itself across a soldier's life and like a virus is brought home to infect everyone he knows. The junk he carries around with him may have no meaning at all.  Just relics taken from the people he had to kill.

comment.author: 48809099@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/old_growth_trees] Wise words indeed. I imagine that the items he collected helped him to rationalise the insanity of war and as you say many soldiers, sailors and airmen were to suffer from PTSD upon their return to Civvy street. My own grandfather joined the Navy aged 15 in 1915 and fought at the Battle of Jutland on H.M.S. Collingwood. He too had souvenirs of the war including a German tobacco tin.

comment.author: 25322997@N03
comment._content: toute l'horreur de cette guerre dans son regard, rien à voir avec les guerres actuelles où les combattants ont une idée sur ce qu'ils défendent; et un espoir d'y arriver. La grande boucherie de 14 en était dépourvue.

comment.author: 94718573@N08
comment._content: I read, somewhere, that actually had a bounty on his head instigated by the Kaiser; whether this was wartime propaganda or not I have no idea.

comment.author: 8139976@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/94718573@N08] Maybe you read this nonsense in Max Arthur's "Faces of World War I", see my comment above. I'm sure the Kaiser had better things to do than to create a personal Most Wanted list for the many soldiers on both sides, like Barney Hines, that were plundering the battle field for souvenirs. There was a whole World War going on, after all. BTW, the picture is said to have been taken after the battle of Polygon Wood, 27 September 1917 (Bill Gammage, The Broken Years: Australian Soldiers in the Great War. Ringwood, Vic.: Penguin Books, 1990, page 274). John "Barney" Hines was a member of the AIF's 45th battalion, born in Liverpool in 1873. More info: (www.awm.gov.au/exhibitions/fiftyaustralians/24.asp)
